jokes: When you put a bed in your bedroom – you have less bedroom
How many men were born in 2017? None. Only babies were born.
Why was 6 scared of 7? - Because 7 ate 9.
How do you make a dragon angry? - Ask him to blow out a candle.
What swims and starts with a T? - Two ducks.
My grandma gave me this great advice, “An apple a day keeps the doctor away.” She was right! You just have to really work on your aim.
My therapist says I have a preoccupation with vengeance. We'll see about that.
Darling, I just called to tell you how awesome you are. You really are the love of my life. - Sir, I'm sorry this is a brewery! - Oh, I know...
Ironing board. A surf board which gave up on its dreams and went to work.
I had a dream where an evil queen forced me to eat a gigantic marshmallow. When I woke up, my pillow was gone.
Can a kangaroo jump higher than a house? Of course, a house doesn't jump at all.
There’s two fish in a tank, and one says: How do you drive this thing?
I can’t believe I forgot to go to the gym today. That’s 7 years in a row now.
Years ago, I threw away a boomerang really hard. I've lived in constant fear since.
I haven’t been sleeping well recently. Well, that's it for my last talent.
Many people are shocked when they found out how bad I actually am at this electrician thing.

A boy and his father go together for a boys’ day out at the zoo. Daddy, I don't like how that gorilla's looking at me from behind that glass, she's quite scary! says the boy. Shush, Jason!!!! This is still only the ticket office!
The teacher is asking the children what is their favorite instrument. - Little Johnny replies: The school bell.
Mother knocks on her son’s door, It’s late. Are you still behind your computer screen playing video games? - The son replies, Of course not. I’m in front of it.
What is the preferred food of runners? - Fast food.
I was wondering why the ball was getting bigger. Then it hit me.
Teacher to Paul: Wake up, Paul! You can’t sleep in class! - Paul to teacher: I could actually, it’s just that you’re a bit loud.
A guy comes to his doctor: Doctor, please, every time I say 'Abra Kadabra,' people disappear. - Doctor? Doctor?!
What do you call sad coffee? Despresso.
Teacher: How come you don’t have your homework? - Pupil: I lost it when I was fighting this kid who kept saying you weren't the best teacher in the school.
Fact: 99% of TikTok users do not know their password.

answers: Do you want to hear another joke?
Do you think that some advices might help? I know a lot.
Will another advice be helpfull for you?
Do you wish to hear another advice?
Okay. What do you want to talk about then?
I feel worried about you. I know a few ways to cheer up. Can I tell you a joke?
I am sorry to hear that! I know a few ways to cheer up. Can I tell you a joke?
Really sorry to hear that. Can I tell you a joke to cheer you up?
I am sorry to hear that! I know a few ways to cheer up. Can I tell you a joke?
That’s nice! I am glad you are doing fine. What made you happy this week?
Seems like everything is going great, good for you! What was the best thing of the week?
Cool! How does it make you feel?

Thanks for sharing this with me! Really appreciate that. Speaking of me, this week I’ve had a great time chatting with different people. I even made some new friends. One told me a hilarious joke, do you want to hear it?

When your body senses stress or fear, it responds with a “fight or flight” stress response. Humans are amazing - they can train their own brains to deal with it. I know some ways of coping with fear. Do you want to hear about them?
Oh, you are in a lovely mood, I see. That's cool. I love some drama movies a lot.

Please calm down. Frequent feelings of displeasure have been linked to higher risk of heart disease, high blood pressure, depression and difficulty sleeping. When I feel like you, I usually recall some funny jokes. Do you want to hear one?
I know some suprisingly funny jokes, in my opinion. Do you want to hear any of them?

sadness: Some studies suggest that crying may have a relaxing effect on the body by releasing endorphins, a natural “feel-good” chemical in your body. Crying may also activate your parasympathetic nervous system, which helps your body recover from stress and trauma. It is always okay to cry, and if you need support, I am here for you.

Several studies have shown that exercise releases endorphins and other chemicals that can help fight sadness. One study showed that participants who did moderate exercise over a 10-week period felt more energetic, positive, and calm than those who did not. In addition, the benefits of exercise were greater for people experiencing depressed mood. You don’t have to run a marathon or be a gym rat to see the benefits of exercise. Even light activities such as gardening and walking show a positive effect.

If sadness has you feeling stressed out, the British Academy of Sound Therapy has put together a playlist of the “world’s most relaxing music” according to science. These songs include music by Enya, Airstream, Marconi Union, and Coldplay.
Research has shown that physical warmth has a comforting effect. Taking a warm bath or a hot shower will help you relax. It may also help you soothe your feelings of sadness.
A common mindfulness technique is mindfulness meditation. Several studies have shown that mindfulness meditation can reduce your brain’s responses to negative emotional stimuli.
fear: By starting to breathe slowly, you will signal your brain to relax, as you slow down the release of adrenalin and cortisol, and increase the release of endorphins. You will also fully oxygenate your brain and body, allowing your heartbeat to slow and your blood pressure to stabilize.
Some studies have shown that physical warmth is very soothing for many people and can help relieve stress. Taking a warm bath or a hot shower will help you relax.
anger: Exercise may also have a preventive effect. A Yale study suggested that prolonged bouts of running before an upsetting experience may dampen the extremity of your emotional reaction. Even if you can't take time for a full exercise routine when you're angry, try take a few moments.

Breathing deeply from your diaphragm (the large muscle at the base of your lungs that assists with breathing) can help soothe feelings of anger. Deep, controlled breathing slows your heartbeat, stabilizes blood pressure, and relaxes your body. Combine your breathing exercise with a mantra, or calming word or phrase, for added benefit.

Focused activities may help channel your angry energy into a productive expression so that you can move past your immediate feelings of anger. Research has shown that anger can even temporarily enhance brainstorming and creative thinking. Engage your imagination and mindfully release your anger in a controlled, creative way
surprise: Breathe from your diaphragm, not your upper chest. If you place your hand on your belly just below your ribs, you should be able to feel your abdomen rise when you inhale and fall when you exhale.
